Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Language structure and number word learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project, to be conducted by researchers at the University of California, San Diego, and Wesleyan University, will study how children between ages 1 and 4 learn number words, the basic building blocks of mathematical learning. The main research question will be how the grammar of a child's native language affects number word learning, leading to earlier or later progress in math. The project will compare different languages (English, Arabic, and Slovenian) that have different grammatical rules for expressions about numbers. This work will help improve understanding of how early language exposure fosters learning about numbers and math. This project will advance the work of the REAL (Research on Education and Learning) program in studying the cognitive basis of STEM (science, technology, engineering, and mathematics) learning.

The project will compare English, Arabic, and two dialects of Slovenian, which vary in terms of grammatical marking for numbers. The research will investigate a syntactic bootstrapping hypothesis in which finer grammatical distinctions support earlier learning. The project will use various age-appropriate measures of number word learning, including looking time, set creation counting, and matching.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we aimed to explore the earliest stages of children’s number word learning. We tested children between one and three years old on number word knowledge, comparing children in two kinds of language environments. We tested children in the U.S. learning English, a singular-plural language. We also tested children in certain regions of Slovenia, where a dialect is used that grammatically marks the dual (sets of two) in addition to the singular and the plural. Previous reports had indicated that children learning a dual-marked language have an advantage when learning small number words, and therefore can learn small number words like “one” and “two” earlier. We hypothesized that we would replicate the finding, and we tested children at even younger ages than had been investigated before, in order to find the earliest time point when children can, in principle, demonstrate knowledge of number words.  

Previous studies had tested children as young as 24 months, but we tested children as young as 18 months. We used a traditional number word task in which we give children a pile of objects and ask them to “give me one”, “give me two”, and so forth. We also developed a simpler looking task, in which children looked at two displays with different numbers of objects (e.g., two objects on one screen and three objects on the other). We played sentences directing children to look at a certain number, and we coded to see how much time the children spent looking at the matching stimulus.  

We did not replicate the previously reported findings that children in dual-marked languages often know the word “two” when they are as young as 24 months old. We investigated whether the looking time method revealed evidence for knowledge in younger children who were too young to cooperate in the other task. In other domains of knowledge, looking time often shows earlier knowledge than behavioral tasks. However, we did not find evidence that children’s looking patterns revealed knowledge of number any earlier than the behavioral task. We conclude that children’s earliest learning of number words is far more variable than previously understood, and that linguistic background such as dual marking is just one of many factors that will affect the timing of children’s number development. We further conclude that the specific method of preferential looking used here, with two simultaneous displays of unfamiliar objects, is not a viable option to reveal number word knowledge in very young children.
